persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: NevilMaskelyne
persons.description: Astronomer Royal and a Commissioner of the Board of Longitude. Contributed to scientifically measuring the density of the Earth. FRSL.

persons.name: ClaudiusPtolemy
persons.description: An Alexandrian mathematician, astronomer, astrologer, geographer, and music theorist. His Almagest supporting a geocentric view of the world was not seriously contradicted until the work of Copernicus.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: JohannesKepler
persons.description: German mathematician, astonomer and natural philosopher who established a precise theory of planetary motion through his three laws.

persons.name: NicolausCopernicus
persons.description: Polish mathematician and astronomer who proposed the theory of that the universe was heliocentric.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: BertholdSchwarz
persons.description: German (or in some accounts Danish or Greek) alchemist, credited with the invention of gunpowder.

persons.name: Muhammad
persons.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

places.name: Constantinople
places.description: The old name for Istanbul, the capital of Turkiye

persons.name: JohnMilton
persons.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: Michelangelo diLodovico Buonarroti Simoni
persons.description: Italian sculptor, painter, architect and poet.

persons.name: GeorgeHandel
persons.description: German-born composer who spent much of his life in Britain, and was buried in Westminster Abbey.
